unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I was navigating the healthcare system for my mom recently, and wow, the amount of identifiers involved is just… something else! I thought I’d share my experience and maybe help someone else avoid the confusion I faced. It’s like a whole other language, right?
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I was navigating the healthcare system for my mom recently, and wow, the amount of identifiers involved is just… something else! I thought I’d share my experience and maybe help someone else avoid the confusion I faced. It’s like a whole other language, right?

unnormalised: First off, there's the UHID. Short for Unique Health Identification Number, this is supposedly THE key to all your medical records across different healthcare providers. My mom’s UHID is something like 123456789012, a 12-digit number we got from the local govt. hospital. But then, each private hospital seems to have its own version.
normalised: First off, there's the U-H-I-D. Short for Unique Health Identification Number, this is supposedly T-H-E key to all your medical records across different healthcare providers. My mom’s U-H-I-D is something like one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two, a twelve-digit number we got from the local government hospital. But then, each private hospital seems to have its own version.

unnormalised: Then you have your insurance policy number. We have a family health insurance policy from ICICI Lombard, and the policy number is something like HLMB/2023/1234567. Trying to remember it while also recalling her UHID was a proper juggling act. It felt like I was auditioning for a role in a circus.
normalised: Then you have your insurance policy number. We have a family health insurance policy from I-C-I-C-I Lombard, and the policy number is something like H-L-M-B slash two thousand and twenty three slash one two three four five six seven. Trying to remember it while also recalling her U-H-I-D was a proper juggling act. It felt like I was auditioning for a role in a circus.

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA) number! It's supposed to act like a health locker, linking all your medical records digitally. Mom's ABHA ID looks like this: 1234-5678-9012-3456. Keeping all these straight is a nightmare, especially when you're already stressed about a loved one's health.
normalised: And let’s not forget the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (A-B-H-A) number! It's supposed to act like a health locker, linking all your medical records digitally. Mom's A-B-H-A I-D looks like this: one two three four hyphen five six seven eight hyphen nine zero one two hyphen three four five six. Keeping all these straight is a nightmare, especially when you're already stressed about a loved one's health.

unnormalised: Plus, doctors often ask for your previous medical record numbers, which are usually hospital-specific. At one hospital, her record number was MRN/2022/00789. It felt like I was playing a guessing game to recall all the different combinations of numbers and letters.
normalised: Plus, doctors often ask for your previous medical record numbers, which are usually hospital-specific. At one hospital, her record number was M-R-N slash two thousand and twenty two slash zero zero seven eight nine. It felt like I was playing a guessing game to recall all the different combinations of numbers and letters.

unnormalised: It's honestly overwhelming, isn't it? I really wish there was a simpler system, maybe just ONE unique identifier that worked everywhere. Maybe this ABHA ID will become that one day? One can hope!
normalised: It's honestly overwhelming, isn't it? I really wish there was a simpler system, maybe just O-N-E unique identifier that worked everywhere. Maybe this A-B-H-A I-D will become that one day? One can hope!

unnormalised: So, my advice? Keep a digital record of all these identifiers - your UHID, ABHA ID, insurance policy number, and any hospital-specific record numbers. A simple spreadsheet or a notes app can save you a lot of time and stress in the long run. Trust me, your future self will thank you!
